text: 0 — Short overview Pitta dosha: fire + a little water — tends to cause heat, acidity, inflammation, irritability, loose stools when imbalanced. Dietary goal for Pitta: cool, moist, slightly astringent or sweet, mildly bitter; reduce hot, spicy, oily, fermented and sour foods. Favor easy-to-digest, cooling preparations and moderate portions. 1 — General principles (rules) • Prioritize cooling foods and preparation methods (steamed, boiled, lightly cooked, soaked). • Prefer sweet, bitter, and astringent rasas; minimize pungent, sour, and salty tastes. • Use mild spices (cardamom, coriander, fennel, turmeric small amounts); avoid red chili, black pepper, garlic, raw onion. • Eat regular meals; avoid long fasting or heavy late-night meals. • Use oils moderately (ghee in small amounts is cooling for Pitta if used sparingly). • Prefer room-temperature or slightly warm drinks; avoid very hot or icy beverages. 2 — Cooling foods (prefer) • Organized by category — use these as primary recommendation lists. • Grains & cereals • Rice (white basmati or boiled rice) — neutral, cooling, easy to digest. • Oats (plain, cooked with water/milk) — soothing, can be flavored with cardamom and almond milk. • Barley (jau) — cooling and grounding; good as khichdi base.

Dairy & alternatives • Milk (cold is generally not recommended; use room temperature or warm with spices) — cooling if not excessive; prefer almond milk or cow’s milk in moderation. • Buttermilk (chaas) — diluted, spiced with roasted cumin and coriander — excellent cooling drink. • Yogurt — use in moderation and preferably diluted with water/seasoning; avoid if it causes acidity for the person. • Legumes & Proteins • Mung dal (split yellow moong) — light, cooling, easiest legume. • Lentils (soaked + well-cooked) — prefer moong and masoor; avoid heavy beans like kidney beans in excess. • White fish or light chicken (if non-vegetarian; in moderation; prefer steamed or boiled). • Nuts: almonds (soaked, peeled) are better; avoid oily nuts like peanuts in excess. Fats & oils • Ghee — only small amounts; traditionally cooling for Pitta when used modestly. • Coconut oil — cooling, good for cooking light foods. • Olive oil — use sparingly. • Herbs & mild spices (prefer) • Coriander (dhania) — cooling. • Fennel (saunf) — helps digestion, cooling. • Cumin (jeera) roasted mildly — in small amounts for digestion. • Cardamom (elaichi), mint, cilantro — cooling and pleasant.

4 — Breakfast options (Pitta-friendly) — short descriptions & quick recipes • Use these as direct suggestions or as seed items for agent selection. Provide 2–3 alternatives per request. • Steamed Moong Dal Khichdi (Pitta-soothing) • What: Split moong dal + rice, cooked soft with turmeric (tiny pinch), a few curry leaves, a dash of ghee. • How to serve: Add grated cucumber, fresh cilantro, and a squeeze of lemon (very small) only if tolerated. Serve warm. • Oatmeal with Almond Milk & Cardamom • What: Rolled oats cooked with almond milk, cardamom, a drizzle of honey (optional), few chopped soaked almonds. • Why: Cooling, grounding, easy on digestion. • Barley Porridge with Fennel • What: Cooked barley with water/almond milk, crushed fennel seeds, a few raisins (optional). • Why: Barley cools and soothes. • Ragi (Finger Millet) Porridge — light • What: Ragi flour cooked into porridge with water or almond milk, mild cardamom. • Use: Good for Pitta when not spicy. • Steamed Idli with Coconut Chutney (mild) • What: Soft idlis; chutney made with fresh coconut, coriander, roasted cumin — no chilies or minimal mild green chili if tolerated.

• Barley Porridge with Fennel • What: Cooked barley with water/almond milk, crushed fennel seeds, a few raisins (optional). • Why: Barley cools and soothes. • Ragi (Finger Millet) Porridge — light • What: Ragi flour cooked into porridge with water or almond milk, mild cardamom. • Use: Good for Pitta when not spicy. • Steamed Idli with Coconut Chutney (mild) • What: Soft idlis; chutney made with fresh coconut, coriander, roasted cumin — no chilies or minimal mild green chili if tolerated. • Why: Light and cooling if chutney is mild. • Fresh Fruit Plate (melon, pear, apple) with a small bowl of soaked almonds • Simple option for mornings with low appetite. • Mung Dal Chilla (light) — made thin, cooked with minimal oil; serve with coriander chutney (mild) or plain yogurt (if tolerated). • Buttermilk (chaas) + toasted whole grain toast (if dairy is tolerated) — buttermilk spiced with roasted cumin and coriander. 5 — Common substitutions (if disliked/allergy) • If allergic to almonds →use soaked sunflower seeds paste in small amounts for creamy texture. 3

• If cannot take dairy →use unsweetened almond milk or oat milk for porridge. • If avoid rice →use barley khichdi instead of rice-moong khichdi. • If dislike moong dal →use well-cooked masoor dal as mild alternative. • If dislike cucumber →use grated apple or grated raw pear (cooling, sweet- astringent). 6 — Simple one-day sample Pitta-balancing meal plan (examples) • Breakfast: Oatmeal with almond milk + cardamom. • Mid-morning: Coconut water or cooling buttermilk. • Lunch: Steamed moong dal khichdi + steamed bottle gourd sabzi + cu- cumber raita (diluted). • Afternoon snack: Fresh pear or apple slices with a pinch of cinnamon. • Evening: Light barley soup or vegetable stew (zucchini, carrots) with coriander. • Dinner: Steamed white fish (optional) or mung dal + steamed vegetables (avoid heavy spices). • Before bed (if needed): Warm almond milk with a pinch of cardamom (only if it soothes the person). 7 — Portioning, timing & practical tips • Prefer moderate portions; avoid heavy meals late at night. • Small snacks between meals are OK if blood sugar requires it; prefer cool- ing fruits. • Encourage hydration with room-temperature water or coconut water; avoid iced drinks.
